contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that emphasizes how unusual it was for a slave to be so honored by the Pharaoh.
contextId.quoteString: he appointed him to be the second most powerful man in all of Egypt!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that Joseph was indeed their brother, even though he knew they would find it very difficut to believe that.
contextId.quoteString: I am your brother, Joseph!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement, because it is surprising that God was able to cause good to happen from the evil thing the brothers did to Joseph.
contextId.quoteString: God used the evil for good!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that Pharaoh not only did not free the Israelites, he made their lives even harder!
contextId.quoteString: he forced them to work even harder!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a command. It is stated as an exclamation because Pharaoh was finally afraid of God and urgently wanted the Israelites to leave Egypt.
contextId.quoteString: Take the Israelites and leave Egypt immediately!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that expresses their certainty that the Egyptians would kill them.
contextId.quoteString: We are going to die!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is both a command and also an exclamation. Moses was telling the people in very strong terms that they were wrong to be afraid, rather than trusting God to protect them.
contextId.quoteString: Stop being afraid!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is both a command and also an exclamation. The Egyptians were so afraid when they realized that they were in great danger.
contextId.quoteString: Run away!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation emphasizes the fear of the Egyptians when they realized that God had led them into a trap in the sea, and they were going to drown.
contextId.quoteString: God is fighting for the Israelites!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that expresses how shocking it was that the people would worship this idol when they had seen what God had done for them.
contextId.quoteString: The people began to wildly worship the idol and make sacrifices to it!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that emphasizes that the land was extremely good.
contextId.quoteString: The land is very fertile and the crops are plentiful!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that emphasizes that the inhabitants of the land were extremely large and powerful soldiers.
contextId.quoteString: The cities are very strong and the people are giants!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that emphasizes that the Israelites were certain the Canaanites would defeat them in battle.
contextId.quoteString: If we attack them, they will certainly defeat us and kill us!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that even though the people of Canaan were large, God was even bigger and would enable the Israelites to defeat them.
contextId.quoteString: It is true that the people of Canaan are tall and strong, but we can certainly defeat them! God will fight for us!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement. It emphasizes how surprising it was that the strong walls fell down when the Israelites blew the trumpets.
contextId.quoteString: Then the walls around Jericho fell down!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that if the idol were truly a god, he would be able to protect himself.
contextId.quoteString: If he is a god, let him protect himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement by the enemy soldier that Gideon would defeat them.
contextId.quoteString: This dream means that Gideon’s army will defeat us, the Midianite army!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that Gideon was depending on Yahweh, and not the sword, for his victory.
contextId.quoteString: A sword for Yahweh and for Gideon!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that Goliath was extremely tall.
contextId.quoteString: about three meters tall!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a surprising statement because people do not live forever.
contextId.quoteString: One of your descendants will rule as king over my people forever!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that expresses that Ahab was very angry with Elijah.
contextId.quoteString: There you are, you troublemaker!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that Elijah uses to rebuke Ahab.
contextId.quoteString: It is you who are the troublemaker!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that the people should decide once for all who they would worship. This does not mean that Elijah was undecided. He knew that Yahweh is the real God. He wanted the people to understand that when they worship false gods, they are rejecting Yahweh as the only true God. Translate this in a way that shows that the people had to make a choice.
contextId.quoteString: If Yahweh is God, worship him! But if Baal is God, worship him!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a both a command and a strong plea for Baal to answer their request and to send fire on the sacrifice.
contextId.quoteString: Hear us, Baal!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This statement is repeated to emphasize that it is indeed true!
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh is God! Yahweh is God!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a both a command and also a strong statement to emphasize that the people must seize every one of the prophets of Baal.
contextId.quoteString: Do not let any of the prophets of Baal escape!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence emphasizes the surprising fact that King Cyrus of the Persians would give the Jews money to rebuild their Temple.
contextId.quoteString: He even gave them money to rebuild the Temple!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence emphasizes that Zechariah and Elizabeth were far too old to have children by natural means. That would require God to work a miracle.
contextId.quoteString: My wife and I are too old to have children!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence emphasizes that God is worthy of praise because of how he helped his people.
contextId.quoteString: Praise God, because he has remembered to help his people!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence emphasizes the exciting message that the Messiah—for whom the Israelites had so long been waiting—had finally come!
contextId.quoteString: The Messiah, the Master, has been born in Bethlehem!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence emphasizes the urgent reason for them to repent—the kingdom of God was near!
contextId.quoteString: Repent, for the kingdom of God is near!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence emphasizes the importance of the statement that follows.
contextId.quoteString: Look!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that Jesus is the Messiah.
contextId.quoteString: “You are the Son of God!”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong statement that it is extremely hard for rich people to be saved.
contextId.quoteString: It is extremely hard for rich people to enter into the kingdom of God!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king said this to emphasize how wicked the servant was.
contextId.quoteString: You wicked servant!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus said this to emphasize that the disciples themselves should find food for the people.
contextId.quoteString: You give them something to eat!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The son said this to emphasize that he was not willing to wait until after his father died in order to receive his inheritance.
contextId.quoteString: I want my inheritance now!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The father is using this expression to show how happy he is that his son has come home.
contextId.quoteString: my son was dead, but now he is alive!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The father is using this expression to show how happy he is that his son has come home.
contextId.quoteString: He was lost, but now we have found him!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The son said this to his father to emphasize that he thought his father was treating him unfairly.
contextId.quoteString: All these years I have worked faithfully for you!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The disciples said this to emphasize the great danger Jesus faced if he went to Judea.
contextId.quoteString: just a short time ago the people there wanted to kill you!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus used this exclamation as a strong command to Lazarus.
contextId.quoteString: Lazarus, come out!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation emphasizes the shocking fact that Lazarus, who had been dead, walked out of the tomb. Some languages should say: “Lazarus came out of the tomb!”
contextId.quoteString: Lazarus came out!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Peter said this to emphasize that he would never abandon Jesus.
contextId.quoteString: Even if all the others abandon you, I will not!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The high priest said this to emphasize the he thought they had already proved that Jesus was guilty of blasphemy.
contextId.quoteString: We do not need any more witnesses to tell us what this man has done!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Jewish leaders said this to emphasize how angry they were with Jesus.
contextId.quoteString: He deserves to die!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant girl said this to accuse Peter of being a criminal.
contextId.quoteString: You also were with Jesus!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a curse that means ‘May God cause harm to me if what you say is true!’ or ‘May God punish me if I am lying to you!’ In this way Peter was saying very strongly that he did not know Jesus. He also referred to Jesus as **this man** to make it sound like he did not know him.
contextId.quoteString: May God curse me if I know this man!

contextId.occurrenceNote: They were saying this to mock Jesus. They were calling Jesus “King of the Jews,” but they did not really believe he was a king.
contextId.quoteString: Look, the King of the Jews!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation emphasizes how surprised they were that the body of Jesus was no longer in the tomb.
contextId.quoteString: His body was not there!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation emphasizes how shocked the disciples were to see Jesus alive again.
contextId.quoteString: That was Jesus!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two disciples used this exclamation to emphasize to the other disciples that Jesus was alive.
contextId.quoteString: Jesus is alive!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two disciples used this exclamation to emphasize that they not only heard that Jesus was alive, but had personally see him.
contextId.quoteString: We have seen him!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Peter used this exclamation to strongly accuse the people in the crowd of murdering Jesus, the Messiah whom God had sent to them.
contextId.quoteString: But you crucified him!

contextId.occurrenceNote: They used this exclamation to express how angry they were with Stephen, and to try to make the other people angry with him as well.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phrases, **in our image** and **like us** are a doublet. They means almost the same thing. Together, they emphasize that man was to be very much like God, although not exactly the same.
contextId.quoteString: in our image to be like us

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words **ordinary** and **uneducated** share similar meanings. They emphasize that Peter and John had received no formal training in Jewish law.
contextId.quoteString: ordinary men who were uneducated

contextId.occurrenceNote: The husband and wife will share an intimate bond of unity and a commitment to one another that will surpass their relationships to anyone else.
contextId.quoteString: becomes one

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression means they now understood something for the first time. This could be translated as: “they saw things differently.” In your language, there may be an expression with similar meaning that you could use to translate this.
contextId.quoteString: their eyes were opened

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means ‘began to think differently than they had before.’ The Egyptians did not replace their minds, but made a decision that was not the same as the one they first made. They decided the Israelites should leave, but later decided that was the wrong choice and that they should have kept the Israelites as slaves. Some languages may not have this same expression, and will express the meaning in a direct way.
contextId.quoteString: changed their minds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to pass from one side to another
contextId.quoteString: cross over

contextId.occurrenceNote: This verbal phrase means ‘discovered.’
contextId.quoteString: found out

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means ‘replace him as king.’ Other ways to say this are: “take his place as king over Israel” or “rule as king instead of him.”
contextId.quoteString: be king in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase **from your heart** is an idiom that means ‘sincerely.’ Alternate translation: “with sincerity” or “truly” or “genuinely” or “honestly.”
contextId.quoteString: from your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: He did not steal the loaves. Alternate translation: “Jesus held the five loaves of bread in his hands”
contextId.quoteString: Jesus took the five loaves of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘were no longer hungry’ or ‘were not hungry anymore.’
contextId.quoteString: were satisfied

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression means ‘looked away from.’ It could also be translated as: “stopped looking at.”
contextId.quoteString: turned his eyes away from

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression means ‘What are you going to do to me?’
contextId.quoteString: What do you want with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: People spoke this traditional blessing when they left each other. Other languages may say something similar such as: “Go well” or “Go with God” or “Peace.” Other ways of translating it could be: “May you have peace as you go” or “Go and know that all is well between us.”
contextId.quoteString: Go in peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means Lazarus has died. Translate this phrase with the normal word for **asleep** in your language. Although Jesus was using this word with a different meaning, the disciples did not understand that yet.
contextId.quoteString: has fallen asleep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **wake** is an idiom that means Jesus would make Lazarus alive again. Translate this phrase with the normal word for **wake** in your language. Although Jesus was using this word with a different meaning, the disciples did not understand that yet.
contextId.quoteString: I must wake him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **pour out** is an idiom that means to give generously and abundantly. Alternate translation: “I will give my Spirit abundantly to all people”
contextId.quoteString: I will pour out my Spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is an idiom that refers to the highest place of honor and authority. Alternate translation: “in the most important position” or “in the place of highest honor.”
contextId.quoteString: at his right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to **raise** is an idiom for causing someone who has died to become alive again. Alternate translation: “whom God caused to live again”
contextId.quoteString: God raised him to life again

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question. The snake asked the woman whether God actually said not to eat from any of the trees in the garden. But he was only pretending that he didn’t know what God had said because he wanted to create doubt in the woman’s mind. He wanted her to question God’s goodness.
contextId.quoteString: Did God really tell you not to eat the fruit from any of the trees in the garden?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question. God already knew the answer to this question. The purpose of the question was to force the man and the woman to explain why they were hiding.
contextId.quoteString: Where are you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Or, “How did you find out that you were naked?” God already knows the answer to all of his questions. By asking this question and the following question, he was giving Adam the opportunity to admit his sin of disobedience. Being naked was not a sin. God created them that way. Their knowledge of their nakedness was the problem. Their shame showed that they had sinned.
contextId.quoteString: Who told you that you were naked?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question. God already knew that Adam had eaten the fruit that God had told him not to eat. This can be translated as: a statement: “You ate the fruit that I told you not to eat!”
contextId.quoteString: Did you eat the fruit I told you not to eat?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Or, “Why have you done this?” God already knew the answer to this question. By asking this question, he was giving the woman the opportunity to admit her guilt. He was also implying that she should not have done what she did.
contextId.quoteString: What have you done?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites were not asking for reasons. Because they were afraid, in this moment they were wishing they had not left Egypt (even though it had been very difficult for them there). This could be a statement: “We should not have left Egypt!”
contextId.quoteString: Why did we leave Egypt?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people were not expecting an answer from Moses or from God. Alternate translation: “You should not have brought us to this horrible place.”
contextId.quoteString: Why did you bring us to this horrible place?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is not a real question that asks for information. Another way of saying this would be: “You should not be trying to help your god” or “You should not need to help your god.”
contextId.quoteString: Why are you trying to help your god?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is not a real question asking for information. Elijah was rebuking the Israelites for repeatedly changing their minds about whether they would serve Yahweh or Baal. Some languages will have to express this as a statement such as “Stop changing your minds about whom you will worship!”
contextId.quoteString: How long will you keep changing your mind?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question. This could also be translated as: “This man is only the son of Joseph!” or “Everyone knows he is just Joseph’s son!” The people were not asking if he was Joseph’s son or not. They were wondering how he could be the Messiah since they thought he was only the son of an ordinary man.
contextId.quoteString: Isn’t this the son of Joseph?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus is not denying that he is good. Rather, he is asking if the ruler understands that Jesus is God.
contextId.quoteString: Why do you call me ‘good’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could also be translated as: “If God does not allow rich people to have eternal life, how can anyone else be saved?” This is perhaps a rhetorical question that means ‘If God does not save rich people, then it seems like he will not save anyone!’
contextId.quoteString: If it is like this, who will God save?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could be translated as: “We cannot do that!” or “It is impossible to do that!” The disciples were not asking an actual question. Rather, they were strongly expressing that they did not think this was possible.
contextId.quoteString: How can we do that?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus uses a question to tell Peter that he should not have doubted. Alternate translation: “you should not have doubted!”
contextId.quoteString: Why did you not trust me to keep you safe?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is not a real question asking for information. The demon was terrified that Jesus would judge him. Some languages will have to express this as a statement such as: “Please do not judge me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God!”
contextId.quoteString: What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘Remember that I told you that you would see God’s power if you believe in me.’ Jesus is not asking this question in order to get an answer, so some languages should translate this as a command.
contextId.quoteString: Did I not tell you that you would see God’s power if you believe in me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘are you really going to betray me with a kiss?’ Jesus is not looking for an answer to this question, so some languages would translate it as a statement, such as: “you are betraying me by kissing me!” or “you make your betrayal even worse by kissing me!”
contextId.quoteString: are you betraying me with a kiss?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This remark appears in the form of a question to reflect Pilate’s belief that no one really knows what truth is. Alternate translation: “Can anyone know what is true?”
contextId.quoteString: What is truth?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The robber does not expect an answer to this question; it is a way that some languages use to make a strong statement. If your language does not use questions in this way, then translate this as: “You should fear God!”
contextId.quoteString: Do you not fear that God will punish you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus uses this rhetorical question to comfort them. Alternate translation: “Do not be frightened.”
contextId.quoteString: Why are you afraid?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus uses this rhetorical question to mildly rebuke them. Jesus was telling them not to doubt that he was alive. Alternate translation: “Do not doubt I am Jesus!” or “Stop doubting!”
contextId.quoteString: Why do you not think it is really I, Jesus?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question communicates a rebuke to Saul. In some languages a statement would be more natural. Alternate translation: “You are persecuting me!” or a command “Stop persecuting me!”
contextId.quoteString: Why are you persecuting me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a merism. **Good** and **evil** are two extremes that represent everything in between them. Satan is saying that they would understand everthing about what is right and wrong.
contextId.quoteString: good and evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a merism. **Good** and **evil** are two extremes that represent everything in between them. God is saying that they would understand everything about what is right and wrong.
contextId.quoteString: good and evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **great nation** is a metonym that means God would cause Abram to have many descendants, and they would become a large and important nation or country.
contextId.quoteString: make you a great nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **sword** is a metonym that refers to their fighting. Alternate translation: “We fight for Yahweh and for Gideon”
contextId.quoteString: sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that people had told Naaman that Elisha was able to perform miracles. Here Elisha is used to represent the miracles that God gave Elisha the power to perform.
contextId.quoteString: Naaman heard about Elisha

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s law will become a part of them, rather than merely being written on stone. Here **heart** represents ‘emotions’ or ‘mind.’ Alternate translation: “My law will be part of their thoughts and emotions”
contextId.quoteString: this would be like writing his law on their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word **world** is a metonym and refers to all the people in the world. Alternate translation: “all the people in the world” or “every person in the world”
contextId.quoteString: world

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **heart** is a metonym for a person’s inner being.
contextId.quoteString: heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **a voice** is a metonym that refers to someone who spoke. This can also be translated as: “a voice spoke from the cloud saying” or “God spoke from the cloud and said.”
contextId.quoteString: a voice coming from the cloud…t said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Roosters often crow about the time the sun comes up, so the hearers might have understood these words as a metonym for the sun coming up. However, the actual crowing of a rooster is an important part of the story later on, so keep the word **rooster** in the translation. Alternate translation: “Before the rooster crows at dawn tomorrow” or “before the rooster crows tomorrow morning.”
contextId.quoteString: before the rooster crows

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym that refers to the time when Jesus will rule. Alternate translation: “when you establish your kingdom” or “when you are ruling as king”
contextId.quoteString: in your kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This statement is a metonym that refers to God’s care. Alternate translation: “I entrust my spirit to your care” or “I give my spirit to you, knowing you will care for it”
contextId.quoteString: I am giving my spirit into your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **name** is a metonym that means both, ‘by the authority of’ and, ‘under the authority of.’ Consider translating the word **name** literally if it will be understood in this way in your language. This phrase can also be repeated as in, ‘in the name of the Father, in the name of the Son, and in the name of the Holy Spirit.’
contextId.quoteString: in the name of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **name** is a metonym that refers to power and authority. Alternate translation: “With the authority of Jesus Christ”
contextId.quoteString: In the name of Jesus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my name” is a metonym that refers to Jesus. Saul will suffer many things because he will tell people about Jesus. Alternate translation: “for me” or “because of me” or “because he serves me” or “because he teaches others about me.”
contextId.quoteString: for my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘by the authority of Jesus.’ Here **name** stands for speaking with the authority or as the representative of Jesus Christ. Because of Jesus’ authority, Paul could command the demon to leave.
contextId.quoteString: In the name of Jesus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **you** is a metonym that refers to his servants. The landowner probably had his servants plant the seeds. Alternate translation: “we planted good seed”
contextId.quoteString: Master, you planted good seed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Another way to say this would be: “tried to seduce Joseph to have sex with her.” To **sleep with** is a way of expressing this in order not to be crude or offensive.
contextId.quoteString: tried to sleep with Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a command from God to all of the Israelites. This could be translated as: “Do not have sexual relations with someone else’s spouse” or “Do not have marital relations with another man’s wife or another woman’s husband.” Be sure to translate this in a way that doesn’t offend or embarrass people. Languages often have an indirect, polite way of saying this, such as: “Do not sleep with.”
contextId.quoteString: Do not commit adultery

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way to say that they were to kill or drive out all the Canaanites out of the Promised Land. This could be translated as: “must get all the Canaanites out of the land” or “must remove from the land all of the Canaanites who are living there.”
contextId.quoteString: you must get rid of all the Canaanites there

contextId.occurrenceNote: In order to be polite, a euphemism is used to say David had sexual intercourse with Bathsheba.
contextId.quoteString: He slept with her

contextId.occurrenceNote: He kept her a virgin until the birth of the baby. In order to be polite, a euphemism is used to say Joseph did not have sexual intercourse with Mary. Alternate translation: “he did not have sexual relations with her”
contextId.quoteString: he did not sleep with her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The woman did not have an open wound; rather, her monthly flow of blood would not stop. Your language may have a polite way to refer to this condition.
contextId.quoteString: a bleeding problem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way to say that Jesus died. This could be translated as: “gave up his spirit to God” or “released his spirit to God and died”
contextId.quoteString: gave up his spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: He became stubborn again and refused to obey God. Here, **heart** is a synecdoche that refers to Pharaoh. Alternate translation: “Pharaoh hardened himself”
contextId.quoteString: hardened his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This does not mean all the Israelite people, just the people who had grown tired of waiting for Moses.
contextId.quoteString: the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: For languages where bread is not a common food, this could be translated as: “food.” In the Jews’ culture, bread was the main food.
contextId.quoteString: bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Make sure that you use the same word to translate **bread** here as you did in [25:02](25/02).
contextId.quoteString: bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **the Jews** refers to the leaders of the Jews. Alternate translation: “the Jewish leaders”
contextId.quoteString: the Jews made a plan to kill Saul

contextId.occurrenceNote: He became stubborn again and refused to obey God. Pharaoh's stubborn attitude is spoken of as if his heart were hard. Alternate translation: “Pharaoh became stubborn”
contextId.quoteString: hardened his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could be translated as: “A tall cloud” or “A cloud shaped like a pillar.” This was not an actual pillar such as something that supports a building. In appearance it resembled a pillar, but it was made out of clouds.
contextId.quoteString: A tall pillar of cloud

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a column of fire that hung or floated in the air in front of the Israelites. This was not an actual pillar such as something that supports a building. It resembled a pillar in appearance, but it was made out of fire.
contextId.quoteString: a tall pillar of fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of his people as if they were priests. Alternate translation: “a kingdom of people who are like priests” or “a kingdom of people who do what priests do”
contextId.quoteString: a kingdom of priests

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor meaning: ‘help his people to understand his laws and to earnestly desire to obey them.’ If possible, keep the image of writing on their hearts, since this is in contrast with the way God had written his law on stone tablets for the Israelites. If that is not possible, you could just translate the meaning.
contextId.quoteString: writing his law on their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: John speaks of the religious leaders as if they were poisonous snakes. Poisonous snakes are dangerous and represent evil. Alternate translation: “You are evil like poisonous snakes!”
contextId.quoteString: You poisonous snakes

contextId.occurrenceNote: John speaks of the religious leaders as if they were trees that bear bad fruit. This metaphor means God is ready to punish sinners. Alternate translation: “God has his axe and he is ready to cut down and burn any tree that grows bad fruit” or “As a person gets his axe ready to cut down and burn a tree that grows bad fruit, God is ready to punish you for your sins”
contextId.quoteString: God will cut down every tree that does not bear good fruit, and he will throw them into the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: John speaks of Jesus as if Jesus is a lamb from God. This is a metaphor that represents God’s perfect sacrifice. Jesus is called the “Lamb of God” because he was sacrificed to pay for people’s sins.
contextId.quoteString: the Lamb of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase **treasure in heaven** is a metaphor that refers to a reward from God. Alternate translation: “God will reward you in heaven”
contextId.quoteString: treasure in heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: A legion was a group of several thousand soldiers in the Roman army. The name **Legion** is a metaphor that speaks of the demons as if they were a large group of soldiers.
contextId.quoteString: “My name is Legion, because we are many.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: The **word** represents God’s message. Sowing the message represents teaching it. Alternate translation: “The sowing of the seed is teaching people God’s message”
contextId.quoteString: The seed is the word of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The **path** represents the person who hears God’s word. Alternate translation: “The path is like the person who hears God’s message”
contextId.quoteString: The path is a person who hears God’s word, but does not understand it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The **rocky ground** represents the person who hears and accepts God’s word for a short time. Alternate translation: “The rocky ground is like the person who hears God’s message and accepts it with joy”
contextId.quoteString: The rocky ground is a person who hears God’s word and accepts it with joy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor speaks of believing God’s word as accepting it. Alternate translation: “joyfully believes it” or “joyfully agrees that it is true”
contextId.quoteString: accepts it with joy

contextId.occurrenceNote: The **thorny ground** represents the person who hears God’s word, but then ignores it. Alternate translation: “The thorny ground is like the person who hears God’s message”
contextId.quoteString: The thorny ground is a person who hears God’s word

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus speaks of a person’s good works as if they were grain.
contextId.quoteString: grain

contextId.occurrenceNote: The **seed in the good soil** represents the person who hears and believes God’s word, and produces fruit as a result. Alternate translation: “The seed in the good soil is like the person who hears and understand God’s message, and then produces fruit”
contextId.quoteString: the seed in the good soil is a person who hears the word of God, believes it, and produces fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus speaks of a person’s good works as if they were fruit.
contextId.quoteString: fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor speaks of the son being gone as if he were lost. This could mean ‘This is like my son was dead and is alive again!’ or ‘I grieved as if my son had died, but now I rejoice because it is as if he has come back to life!’
contextId.quoteString: my son was dead, but now he is alive!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor speaks of the son being gone as if he were lost. This could mean ‘This is like my son was lost and I have found him again!’ or ‘I grieved as if my son were lost, but now I rejoice because it is as if I have found him again!’
contextId.quoteString: He was lost, but now we have found him!

contextId.occurrenceNote: See how you translated this in [35:09](35/09).
contextId.quoteString: was dead, but now is alive

contextId.occurrenceNote: See how you translated this in [35:09](35/09).
contextId.quoteString: He was lost, but now we have found him!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Do not use Jesus’ name in this quote because the prophet who first wrote it would not have known the shepherd’s name. Also, do not refer to the sheep being the disciples. It is best to use words that mean **shepherd** and **sheep** in your translation.
contextId.quoteString: the shepherd and all the sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus speaks of the work that he must do, including dying on the cross, as if it were a bitter liquid that God has commanded him to drink from a cup. Alternate translation: “go through this suffering” or “suffer what is about to happen” or “endure this suffering.”
contextId.quoteString: drink this cup of suffering

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **turn** is a metaphor for starting to obey the Lord. Alternate translation: “start obeying the Lord”
contextId.quoteString: turn to God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Peter is speaking of God’s forgiveness for sinners as if God were physically washing them.
contextId.quoteString: he will wash away your sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: How a person can be saved is spoken of here as if it were a way or path that a person walks on. Alternate translation: “how you can be saved” or “how God saves people” or “God’s plan for saving people”
contextId.quoteString: the way to be saved

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words **fields** and **ripe for harvest** are metaphors. The **fields** represent people. The words **ripe for harvest** mean that people are ready to accept the message of Jesus, like fields that are ready to be harvested. Alternate translation: This could also be translated as: “They are ready to be brought to God like fields that are ripe for harvest” or “They are ready to be gathered and brought to God like fields whose crops are ripe and ready to be gathered.”
contextId.quoteString: The fields are ripe for harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization to refer to the leaders and people who represent the ten tribes of the northern kingdom.
contextId.quoteString: all the people of the kingdom of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not every person in the land of Israel came to Mount Carmel. This is a generalization to refer to the leaders and people who represent the ten tribes of the northern kingdom.
contextId.quoteString: all the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggerated statement in order to emphasize the difficulty of a rich person being saved.
contextId.quoteString: it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1. this is a simile, and the Spirit descended upon Jesus as a bird descends from the sky toward the ground or 2. the Spirit literally looked like a dove as he descended upon Jesus.
contextId.quoteString: Spirit of God appeared in the form of a dove and came down and rested on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: That is, he should love his neighbor to the same extent that he loves himself.
contextId.quoteString: as yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘as much as you love yourself’ or ‘to the same degree that you love yourself.’
contextId.quoteString: as you love yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: Other ways to say this are: “God’s rule over people is like” or “The way God rules people can be compared to.”
contextId.quoteString: The kingdom of God is like

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could be translated as: “vulnerable and lost, just like sheep are when they have no shepherd to take care of them.”
contextId.quoteString: like sheep without a shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus speaks of the person as if he is like stalks of wheat.
contextId.quoteString: He is like wheat stalks

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile speaks of the kingdom of God as if it were a mustard seed.
contextId.quoteString: The kingdom of God is like a mustard seed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kingdom of God is spoken of as if it were yeast that is mixed into dough.
contextId.quoteString: The kingdom of God is like yeast

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kingdom of God is spoken of as if it were a hidden treasure in a field.
contextId.quoteString: The kingdom of God is also like treasure

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kingdom of God is spoken of as if it were a perfect pearl that was worth a lot of money.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how bright Jesus’ appearance became.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how white Jesus’ clothes became.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a simile that means the soldiers fell down and did not move, just like dead men do not move. They probably had fainted from fright. To make this clear, this could be translated as: “suddenly fell to the ground and did not move.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could also be translated as: “be glorious like the sun” or “show pure goodness as the sun shows bright light.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘love others, even your enemies.’ Make sure it does not sound like “the same” is only referring to helping a wounded man.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an ellipse. The missing information can be stated: “were very afraid of Jesus and asked him to leave.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: They were saying this to mock Jesus. They did not really believe he was a king, and yet what they were saying was true.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people were mocking Jesus, but he truly was the Son of God.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘do not consider them guilty of the sin of killing me.’ This can be stated in a positive way. Alternate translation: “forgive them for this sin”

contextId.occurrenceNote: The man and the woman tried to cover their bodies in order to hide from God because they were ashamed that they were naked. You may want to make that explicit. Alternate translation: “They were ashamed that they were naked, and tried to cover their bodies to hide from God”

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that God knows that Abraham has another son, Ishmael. This emphasizes that Isaac is the son that God promised to give Abraham. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “your only son whom I have promised”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ishmael was also Abraham’s son, but Isaac was the only son of Abraham and Sarah. God’s covenant was with Isaac and it was through Isaac that God would fulfill his promise. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “your only son whom I have promised”
contextId.quoteString: your only son

contextId.occurrenceNote: The interpretation of dreams was important in the ancient Near East. It was seen as possible only through divine power. This can be clearly stated: “God did not enable any of his advisors to tell him the meaning of the dreams..’”
contextId.quoteString: None of his advisors could tell him the meaning of the dreams.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh gave Joseph the power to interpret dreams in order to bring himself glory and to protect Joseph and the Hebrew people. This can be clearly stated: “God had given Joseph the ability to interpret dreams in order to protect Joseph and the Hebrew people.”
contextId.quoteString: God had given Joseph the ability to interpret dreams

contextId.occurrenceNote: They returned to where the rest of the Israelites were waiting, just outside the border of Canaan. This can be clearly stated: “they returned to the camp of the Israelites.’”
contextId.quoteString: they came back

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **know** means to learn by experience, suggesting Zechariah was asking for a sign as proof. Alternate translation: “What can you do to prove to me that this will happen?”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Parents normally arranged the marriages of their children. Alternate translation: “The parents of Mary had promised her in marriage to a righteous man named Joseph”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joseph had not married Mary yet, but when a man and woman promised to marry each other, Jews considered them husband and wife though they did not live together. This is why a divorce was necessary rather than simply breaking an engagement. For some languages, it may be better to say: “break their engagement.”
contextId.quoteString: divorce her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Because God sent the angel, the angel knew the baby was a boy.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Satan knew that Jesus was indeed **the Son of God**.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus refused to do what Satan asked. This can be clearly stated: “But Jesus said to Satan, ‘No, I will not do that because it is written …’”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Satan knew that Jesus was indeed **the Son of God**.
contextId.quoteString: If you are the Son of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jesus refused to do what Satan asked. This can be clearly stated: “But Jesus said to Satan, ‘No, I will not do that. Get away from me, Satan.’”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was surprising because the Levites served in the Temple, and would have been expected to help their fellow Jew.
contextId.quoteString: He also ignored that man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was surprising because the the Jews and Samaritans hated each other, so he would not have been expected to help the Jewish man.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘greatly astonished.’ They believed that God made people rich because they were more righteous than other people.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here **first** and **last** refer to people’s status or importance. Jesus is contrasting people’s status now with their status in the kingdom of heaven. Alternate translation: “But many who seem to be important now will be the least important, and many who seem to be unimportant now will be very important”
contextId.quoteString: many who are first will be last, and many who are last will be first

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated that the reason the man would be sold was so that the money received from selling him could pay part of what he owed to they king.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘commanded his guards to put.’ Consider how **threw** was translated in frame [29:06](29/06).

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to looking up, toward the sky. The Jews believed that heaven was located above the sky.

contextId.occurrenceNote: You can make explicit what Peter should not have doubted. Alternate translation: “you should not have doubted that I could keep you from sinking!”

contextId.occurrenceNote: If you need to be more specific, it can be stated what they were amazed by. Alternate translation: “They were completely amazed at what he had done”

contextId.occurrenceNote: According to Jewish law, she was not supposed to touch anyone. She touches his clothes so that Jesus’ power would heal her and yet (she thought) he would not know that she touched him.

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to explain that tribulation comes because people believe God’s message. Alternate translation: “he suffers because he believe God’s message”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Mustard seeds were the smallest seeds known to the original hearers.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be translated as: “leaven” or “the little bit of leaven.” It is added to bread dough to make it rise. A little bit of yeast mixed into a large amount of dough makes the whole batch of dough rise.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the person buys the field to take possession of the hidden treasure. This can be clearly stated: “so he could buy that field to make the treasure his own.’”
contextId.quoteString: so he could buy that field where the treasure was

contextId.occurrenceNote: Religious leaders thought that they themselves were the best examples of righteous good people, and they thought that tax collectors were the most unrighteous sinners.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Pharisees believed that tax collectors were as sinful as robbers, unrighteous people, and adulterers. This could be made explicit. Alternate translation: “and I am certainly not like this sinful tax collector who cheats people”

contextId.occurrenceNote: The father did this to show his son that he loved him and was glad that the son was coming home. If people think that it is strange or wrong for a man to embrace or hug and kiss his son, you can substitute a way that men in your culture show affection to their sons. Alternate translation: “welcomed him affectionately”
contextId.quoteString: hugged him and kissed him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wealthy people of that time wore sandals. However, in many cultures the modern equivalent would be ‘shoes.’

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression shows that the older son was angry. It shows his rejection of his younger brother and his disapproval of his father for welcoming back this wayward son. Other languages may also have an indirect way of communicating these things.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The father refers to his younger son as **your brother** to remind the older son of his relationship to the younger son and of how he should love his younger brother.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be translated as: “The final result of this sickness will not be the death of Lazarus” or “Lazarus is sick, but death is not the final result of this sickness.” Jesus’ disciples probably thought this meant that Lazarus would not die. But Jesus knew that, although Lazarus would die from his sickness, he would live in the end.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he broke the bread into pieces for the people to eat. Alternate translation: “broke it into pieces” or “ripped it” or “tore it.” He may have divided it into many pieces or he may have divided it into two pieces and given them to the apostles to divide among themselves. If possible, use an expression that would apply to either situation.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘I will kill.’ Here **I** refers to God. It is implied that God will cause or allow people to harm and kill Jesus.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means ‘if God would allow it to happen.’ Alternate translation: “if you will allow it”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Good friends would kiss each other on the cheek, but a disciple would probably kiss his master on the hand to show respect. No one knows for sure how Judas kissed Jesus.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant girl could probably tell Peter was from Galilee from the way he talked.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘they do not understand the meaning of what they are doing, so please forgive them.’ The soldiers thought Jesus was only a criminal who deserved to die. contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean ‘played a game of chance to win Jesus’ clothes.’ We do not know how they did this, but in some cultures it could be translated as: “tossed stones on the ground to win Jesus’ clothing” or “chose sticks to decide who could take Jesus’ clothes.” The winner received his clothing.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people were mocking Jesus. Alternate translation: “We do not believe you are the King of the Jews, but if you are”

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was the custom of the Jews to wash the body and then wrap it with strong, pleasant smelling spices to prevent the dead body from smelling bad so quickly. This was also a sign of honor and devotion.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could be translated as: “in languages other than their own language” or “in foreign languages” or “as people from other places speak.” The believers did not know these languages until the Holy Spirit gave them the power to speak them. contextId.occurrenceNote: They did not go into the Temple building where only the priests were allowed. Alternate translation: “to the Temple courtyard” or “into the Temple area”

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that Peter has the ability to heal the man.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Ethiopian was intelligent and could read, but he lacked spiritual discernment. Alternate translation: “Do you understand the meaning of what you are reading?”

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied here that Philip agreed to travel down the road with him to explain the scriptures.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to men and women who believed in Jesus.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul’s purpose can be made clear by adding “so that the Jewish leaders could judge and punish them.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: The gates were the only normal way into or out of the walled cities.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Some languages would say: “went out” instead.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The motion is away from the speaker, Pharaoh. Moses is commanded to take the Israelites away from Pharoah and continue moving with them until they have left all of Egypt, the country where the speaker is located.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites were to go from where they were camped to the land of Canaan and spy in the land of Canaan.

contextId.occurrenceNote: A **herd** is a large group of animals. Use a similar word in your language.

contextId.occurrenceNote: A **reed** is a type of tall grass that grew in flat, wet areas. Use a similar word in your language.

contextId.occurrenceNote: A **flock of sheep** is a large group of sheep that are owned by someone. Use a similar word in your language.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name emphasizes that God is the only one who has always lived and always will live.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** connects the action (the Israelites arriving safely on the other side of the Sea) with God’s instructions to Moses to close the path through the sea.
contextId.quoteString: Then God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **After** introduces sequential action. The Israelites obeyed God by passing from one side of the Jordan to the other. Once that was completed, God gave another task for them to do. In some languages, it is better to say: “The people crossed the Jordan River and then…”
contextId.quoteString: After the people crossed the Jordan River

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces sequential action. The priests were to blow their trumpets after the Israelites had finished marching around the city seven times.
contextId.quoteString: Then the priests must blow their trumpets

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. The Israelites followed all of God’s commands, and then this event happened.
contextId.quoteString: Then the walls

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **After** introduces sequential action. God defeated one large army made up of many smaller armies. Then another large army, also made up of many smaller armies, came against Israel.
contextId.quoteString: After God defeated those armies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. The fighting of the battles and the dividing of the Promised Land were completed, and then God gave Israel peace along its borders. OR Fighting the battles and dividing the Promised Land were completed. Then God gave Israel peace along its borders.
contextId.quoteString: Then God gave Israel peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** indicates sequential action. God called Gideon, and then the Midianites returned.
contextId.quoteString: Then the Midianites came again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause that connects Gideon hearing the dream and worshiping God with him rallying the 300 Israelites to fight the Midianites.
contextId.quoteString: Then Gideon returned to his soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. Gideon’s men surrounding the Midianite camp, and then they broke their pots at the same moment.
contextId.quoteString: Then, all of Gideon’s soldiers broke their pots

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Finally** indicates a shift from the time of deliverers sent by God to the time when Israel asked God for a king. This could be translated as: “After their enemies attacked them many times” or “After many years of being attacked by many different nations…”
contextId.quoteString: Finally

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **After that** indicate the sequence of events. The first enemy of Israel that David defeated was Goliath, but after defeating Goliath, David went on to defeat many other enemies of Israel.
contextId.quoteString: After that

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **After** introduces a sequential clause. Uriah died, and then David married Bathsheba.
contextId.quoteString: After Uriah died

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **After** introduces a sequential clause that indicates Solomon died and then Rehoboam became king.
contextId.quoteString: After Solomon died

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **After that** introduce a sequential clause. Elijah prepared the sacrifice, and then had people pour 12 pots of water over it.
contextId.quoteString: After that

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Immediately** emphasizes that the fire fell from the sky as soon as Elijah prayed. In contrast, the prayers of the prophets of Baal were still not answered after hours of praying.
contextId.quoteString: Immediately

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. The prophets of Baal were killed, and then Elijah warned Ahab.
contextId.quoteString: Then Elijah said to King Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting clause **When he came up from the water the last time** introduces a sequential clause. Naaman dipped himself seven times, and then God healed him.
contextId.quoteString: When he came up from the water the last time

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **After that** introduce a sequential clause. They killed the king’s sons and blinded him in Judah, and then took him to a prison in Babylon.
contextId.quoteString: After that, they took the king away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Immediately** introduces a sequential clause. First the angel said Zechariah would not be able to speak, and the next thing that happened was Zechariah could not speak.
contextId.quoteString: Immediately, Zechariah was unable to speak

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Soon** introduces a sequential clause. The angel came to Mary and soon after Mary left to visit Elizabeth.
contextId.quoteString: Soon after this happened

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. After Zechariah and Elizabeth named their baby John, Zechariah was able to speak again.
contextId.quoteString: Then God made Zechariah able to speak again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **and** introduces a sequential clause. After they go and search for the baby, they will find him wrapped in cloth and lying in a trough.
contextId.quoteString: and you will find him wrapped in pieces of cloth and lying in a feeding trough

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. The angels gave their praise, and then they left.
contextId.quoteString: Then the angels left

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a sequential clause. First, they heard John’s message, then they would repent and John would baptize them.
contextId.quoteString: When people heard John’s message, many of them repented from their sins, and John baptized them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **After** introduces a sequence of events. The Jewish leaders spoke to Pilate after he had had Jesus crucified.
contextId.quoteString: After the soldiers crucified Jesus

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Before** introduces a sequential clause. First there was the earthquake and appearance of the angel, and then the women arrived at the tomb.
contextId.quoteString: Before the women arrived, there was a great earthquake at the tomb

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **After** introduces a sequential clause. First Jesus returned to heaven. Then the disciples waited in Jerusalem.
contextId.quoteString: After Jesus returned to heaven, the disciples stayed in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Immediately** introduces a sequential clause. Peter spoke, and then the lame man was healed. But the writer wants the readers to know there was no delay—the healing took place as soon as Peter spoke.
contextId.quoteString: Immediately, God healed the lame man

contextId.occurrenceNote: ‘the demon came out immediately’
contextId.quoteString: Right away the demon left her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **Then** introduces a sequential clause. After the Jesus followers who died rise to meet Jesus in the air, the Jesus followers who are still alive will also join Jesus.
contextId.quoteString: Then the followers of Jesus who are still alive

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **After that** introduce a sequential clause. After Jesus followers have joined Jesus, they will live together forever.
contextId.quoteString: After that, Jesus will live with his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a sequential clause. After Jesus returns, he will destroy Satan and his kingdom.
contextId.quoteString: When Jesus returns

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jacob had lived for twenty years in the land where his mother was from. If that is not clear you could say: “After twenty years living in the land where his relatives were…”
contextId.quoteString: After 20 years

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a background clause that indicates Solomon became old at the beginning of the time when he worshiped foreign gods.
contextId.quoteString: When Solomon was old

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a background clause which indicates that at the same time the people of the kingdom of Israel started worshiping idols, they also started sleeping with prostitutes and sacrificing children to idols.
contextId.quoteString: When they did this

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a background clause. The main event is Mary’s pregnancy and visit to Elizabeth. The background event that was already happening is Elizabeth was six months pregnant.
contextId.quoteString: When Elizabeth was six months pregnant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information about the sacrifices the priests offered to God in the past.
contextId.quoteString: For hundreds of years, priests kept on offering sacrifices to God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This clause gives background information about the time during the last plague on Egypt. The main event is the Passover that shows how God will pay for people’s sins.
contextId.quoteString: When God sent the last plague on Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a conditional statement. The blessings are dependent on the Israelites obeying the commandments God had given.
contextId.quoteString: If you do this

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **if** indicates a hypothetical conditional relationship. God’s blessing depends on the Israelites obeying the laws.
contextId.quoteString: if they obeyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **if** indicates a hypothetical conditional relationship. God would punish the Israelites if they did not obey the laws.
contextId.quoteString: if they did not obey

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If the Israelites do not obey God by driving out the Canaanites, in time they will also disobey God by worshiping the idols of the Canaanites.
contextId.quoteString: If you do not obey me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** indicates a hypothetical conditional relationship. If God sends fire, then it proves that he is real.
contextId.quoteString: if God sends fire on the altar

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical condition. The result depended on Israel’s response to the warning of the prophets. God said that, if they did not stop doing evil, he would punish them.
contextId.quoteString: If the people did not do this

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. The Jewish leaders thought that the disciples would only be able to say Jesus had risen from the dead if they were able to steal his body.
contextId.quoteString: If they do, they will say he has risen from the dead

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If people repent, then God will forgive their sins. If they do not repent, then he will not forgive their sins.
contextId.quoteString: If they repent, God will forgive their sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you believe in Christ, then God will forgive your sins.
contextId.quoteString: If you believe this

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you believe in Jesus and confess what he has done for you, then you are a Christ follower.
contextId.quoteString: If you believe in Jesus and confess what he has done for you, you are a follower of Jesus!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you are a Christ follower, then God has forgiven your sins and you are his close friend.
contextId.quoteString: If you are a follower of Jesus

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you are a friend of God, then you want to obey Jesus.
contextId.quoteString: If you are a friend of God and a servant of Jesus the Master

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **if** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you confess your sins, then God will forgive you.
contextId.quoteString: if you confess your sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **If** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you do the things God tells you to do, then you will become a strong friend of his.
contextId.quoteString: If you do all these things

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **if** introduces a hypothetical conditional relationship. If you remain faithful to the end, then God will save you.
contextId.quoteString: If you remain faithful to me to the end, then God will save you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **even though** represent a factual condition. The city of Jericho was indeed very strong, so attacking of the city would seem to be an unwise choice.
contextId.quoteString: even though it was very strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **even though** introduce a factual condition. Baptism is sign of repentance, but Jesus never sinned, so he had no need to repent. Jesus’ sinlessness was not questioned even though the evidence, his baptism, would seem to say he had repented of sin.
contextId.quoteString: even though Jesus had never sinned

contextId.occurrenceNote: **Finally** connects the reason for Saul’s jealousy (the people loved David) with the result of Saul’s jealousy (Saul wanted to kill David).
contextId.quoteString: Finally

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **and** is acting as more than a simple conjunction. It indicates that God’s blessing on David included his military efforts. David won many battles not because he was a great soldier, though he was, but because God helped him defeat Israel’s enemies.
contextId.quoteString: and God helped him defeat

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **Of course** indicate that David did not know when God would do these things, since God did not tell him when they would happen.
contextId.quoteString: Of course

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not stated whether he chose not to eat or drink as a form of worship, or if he had no appetite because he was too distressed from his situation. It is preferable not to specify the reason.
contextId.quoteString: Saul did not eat or drink anything for three days

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting words **During this time** introduce a simultaneous clause. At the same time as Elijah was hiding in the wilderness, Ahab and his army were looking for him but could not find him.
contextId.quoteString: During this time

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a simultaneous clause. When they saw Jesus, the wisemen bowed down and worshiped. It was their simultaneous response to seeing him.
contextId.quoteString: When these men saw Jesus with his mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word **When** introduces a simultaneous clause. The two events happened at the same time, the women arrived at the tomb and the angel spoke to them.
contextId.quoteString: When the women arrived at the tomb, the angel told them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word **While** introduces a simultaneous clause. The two events happened at the same time—the believers were together, and there was a sound like a strong wind.
contextId.quoteString: While the believers were all together

contextId.occurrenceNote: This introduces a simultaneous clause. Saul was able to see as soon as Ananias touched him.
contextId.quoteString: Immediately

contextId.occurrenceNote: The connecting word **When** introduces a simultaneous clause. Jesus’ followers who have died will rise and meet him in the sky at the time of Jesus’ return.
contextId.quoteString: When Jesus returns

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an important title for Jesus. Mary will bear **a son** who will be called **the Son of the Most High**. Jesus is therefore a human son born of a human mother, and he is also the Son of God. These terms should be translated very carefully.
contextId.quoteString: Son of the Most High God

contextId.quoteString: the Son of God
